data.concept: CSS describes how HTML should look using selectors to target elements and properties to control color, spacing, typography, and other visual aspects.
Classes apply reusable styles to multiple elements, while ids uniquely identify a single element, and naming conventions help keep styles predictable.
Flexbox arranges items along a single axis, while CSS Grid creates two‑dimensional layouts with rows and columns, both supporting gaps and responsive changes.
Pseudo‑classes like :hover, :focus, and :active style elements in response to user interaction, and transitions smooth visual changes for a modern feel.
CSS controls the visual presentation of HTML by matching selectors to elements and applying property–value pairs, keeping structure and design logically separated.
Different selector types target elements with varying strength, and the browser resolves conflicts by specificity: inline styles override ids, which override classes, which override type selectors.
The cascade combines origin, specificity, and source order, while many text-related properties inherit from parent to child; the !important flag should be used rarely to force a value.
Every element is a rectangular box with content, padding, border, and margin, and box-sizing controls whether width and height include padding and border or not.
CSS colors can be expressed as named values, hex, rgb, or hsl, and backgrounds may be solid, image-based, or gradients layered together for modern UI effects.
Typography rules configure fonts, sizing scale, line spacing, and letter spacing to make content legible and consistent across headings, body text, and UI labels.
The display property chooses how elements participate in layout, while positioning schemes like relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky control how boxes are placed and layered.
Flexbox arranges items along a main axis with powerful alignment and distribution options, ideal for toolbars, cards rows, and responsive single-dimensional layouts.
CSS Grid provides two-dimensional control over rows and columns, letting designers define templates and place items precisely, which suits dashboards and editor layouts.
Media queries apply different style blocks based on viewport width or other conditions, enabling layouts that adapt to mobiles, tablets, and large screens.
Pseudo-classes style elements according to interaction state, such as hover or keyboard focus, which is essential for accessible, tactile feedback in buttons and links.
Pseudo-elements create virtual elements before or after real content, useful for decorative shapes, status dots, and small labels without extra HTML nodes.
Transitions interpolate property changes smoothly over time, while keyframe animations define more complex sequences like pulsing buttons or floating cards.
Shadows, rounded corners, and outlines shape the perceived depth and focus of UI components, distinguishing cards, modals, and interactive controls.
CSS custom properties store reusable values such as colors and spacing tokens, making it easier to theme dashboards and switch between light and dark modes.
Organizing styles into small utilities and larger components keeps a design system maintainable, and naming patterns or scoping techniques prevent clashes in big apps.
JavaScript runs inside the browser to add interactivity to web pages, using statements and expressions that are loaded via script tags or external files.
data.exampleCode:
<script>
  console.log("Welcome to Learn Peak");
</script>

<script src="/scripts/app.js"></script>

data.concept: Variables declared with let and const store values such as numbers, strings, and booleans, and JavaScript determines the type dynamically at runtime.
Operators combine values into expressions, including arithmetic for math, comparison for true or false checks, and logical operators for complex conditions.
data.exampleCode:
let score = 42 + 8;      // arithmetic
let passed = score >= 50; // comparison
let allowNext = passed || score === 49; // logical
console.log(score, passed, allowNext);

data.concept: Conditional statements choose different code paths based on boolean tests, using if/else chains, switch cases, or compact ternary operators for simple decisions.
Loops repeat code over ranges or collections, and JavaScript provides classic for and while loops as well as higher level iteration over arrays.
Functions group reusable logic that can accept parameters and return values, and arrow functions provide a concise syntax for inline callbacks.
Arrays hold ordered lists of values and provide methods for adding, removing, and transforming items, which is essential for handling lists of data in apps.
Objects group related data and behavior into key–value pairs, letting you model entities such as users, courses, or UI state with readable property access.
The DOM API lets JavaScript read and update HTML elements, changing text, attributes, and classes to respond to user interactions in real time.
Event listeners run functions when users interact with the page, such as clicking buttons, typing in inputs, or submitting forms, making the UI dynamic.
JSON represents structured data using JavaScript-like object syntax, and parse and stringify convert between JSON strings and in-memory objects for APIs.
Asynchronous code retrieves data from servers without blocking the UI, using promises and the async/await syntax to write readable async workflows.
ES modules split JavaScript into separate files that export values and functions, which can then be imported where needed to keep large projects organized.
Errors can be caught and handled with try/catch blocks, while console logging and browser devtools help you inspect variables and step through code.
